verses.verse: ((1, 2 Eliphaz showeth the difference between the children of God and the wicked.3 The fall of the wicked.9 God’s power who destroyeth the wicked, and delivereth his.) ) Call now, if any will (He willeth Job to consider the example of all them that have lived or do live godly, whether any of them be like unto him in raging against God as he doth.) answer thee, and to which of the Saints wilt thou turn?
Doubtless (Murmuring against God in afflictions increaseth the pain, and uttered man’s folly.) anger killeth the foolish, and envy slayeth the idiot.

I have seen the (That is, the sinner that hath not the fear of God.) foolish well rooted, and suddenly I (I was not moved with his prosperity, but knew that God had cursed him and his.) cursed his habitation, saying,

His (Though God sometimes suffer the fathers to pass in this world, yet his judgments will light upon their wicked children.) children shall be far from salvation, and they shall be destroyed in the (By public judgment they shall be condemned, and none shall pity them.) gate, and none shall deliver them.

The hungry shall eat up his harvest: yea, they shall take it from among the (Though there be but two or three ears left in the hedges, yet these shall be taken from him.) thorns, and the thirsty shall drink up their substance.
For misery cometh not forth of the dust, (That is, the earth is not the cause of barrenness and man’s misery, but his own sin.) neither doeth affliction spring out of the earth.
But man is born unto (Which declareth that sin is ever in our corrupt nature: for before sin it was not subject to pain and affliction.) travail, as the sparks fly upward.
But I would inquire at (If I suffered as thou doest, I would seek unto God.) God, and turn my talk unto God:

Which (He counselleth Job to humble himself unto God to whom all creatures are subject and whose works declare that man is inexcusable except he glorify God in all his works.) doeth great things, and unsearchable, and marvelous things without number.
He (He showeth by particular examples, what the works of God are.) giveth rain upon the earth, and poureth water upon the streets,
And setteth up on high them that be low, that the sorrowful may be exalted to salvation.
He scattereth the devices of the crafty: so that their hands cannot accomplish that which they do enterprise.
(Cross references: : 1 Cor. 3:19) He taketh the wise in their craftiness, and the counsel of the wicked is made foolish.

They meet with (In things plain and evident they show themselves fools instead of wise men.) darkness in the daytime, and (This declareth that God punisheth the worldly wise, as he threatened, Deut. 28:29.) grope at noonday, as in the night.

But he saveth the (That is, he that humbleth himself before God.) poor from the sword, from their (He compareth the slander of the wicked to sharp swords.) mouth, and from the hand of the violent man,
So that the poor hath his hope, but iniquity shall (If the wicked be compelled at God’s works to stop their mouths, much more they that profess God.) stop her mouth.
Behold, blessed is the man whom God correcteth: therefore refuse not thou the chastising of the Almighty.
For he maketh the wound, and bindeth it up: he smiteth, and his hands make whole.

He shall deliver thee in (He will send trouble after trouble that his children may not for one time, but continually trust in him: but they shall have a comfortable issue, even in the greatest and the last, which is here called the seventh.) six troubles, and in the seventh the evil shall not touch thee.
In famine he shall deliver thee from death: and in battle from the power of the sword.
Thou shalt be hid from the scourge of the tongue, and thou shalt not be afraid of destruction when it cometh.
But thou shalt (Whereas the wicked lament in their troubles, thou shalt have occasion to rejoice.) laugh at destruction and dearth, and shalt not be afraid of the beast of the earth.
For the stones of the field (When we are in God’s favor, all creatures shall serve us.) shall be in league with thee, and the beasts of the field shall be at peace with thee.

And thou shalt know, that peace shall be in thy tabernacle, and thou shalt visit thine habitation, and shalt not (God shall so bless thee, that thou shalt have occasion to rejoice in all things, and not to be offended.) sin.
Thou shalt perceive also that thy seed shall be great, and thy posterity as the grass of the earth.

Thou shalt go to thy grave in (Though the children of God have not always this promise performed, yet God doth recompense it otherwise to their advantage.) a full age, as a rick of corn cometh in due season into the barn.

Lo, (We have learned these points by experience, that God punisheth not the innocent, that man cannot compare in justice with him, that the hypocrites shall not long prosper, and that the affliction which man sustaineth, cometh for his own sin.) thus have we inquired of it, and so it is: hear this and know it for thyself.
